subject: RE: [junit] Exception Handling Question
msgSnippet: I think RubyUnit has a great way to test for exceptions. Using RubyUnit you can say: def testFoo ... assert_exception( NoSuchThingyExpception ) {
messageBody:
I think RubyUnit has a great way to test for exceptions.

Using RubyUnit you can say:

def testFoo
...
assert_exception( NoSuchThingyExpception ) { someObj.someMethod }
end

If the code block (the part inside the braces} throws the
NoSuchThingyException, then the test passes, otherwise it fails. I think
having the explicit 'assert_exception' makes your intentions for the test
more clear.

In Java this could be accomplished with a Runnable interface:

void testFoo() {
...
assertException( NoSuchThingyException.class, new Runnable() {
public void run() {
someObj.someMethod();
}
} );
}
}

This doesn't seem as clean as the Ruby example. It does make it clear that
you are testing for an exception, though. Is this something that would be
useful to have in the JUnit framework?

For more about Ruby see http://www.ruby-lang.org/en/index.html

Matt
